image.altText: A woman with long black hair stands in front of a microphone looking serious.

props.synopsis: Former leader Jeremy Hanson is challenging Ms Lee for the top spot.

title.children: 'I'm the best person': Elizabeth Lee to recontest Canberra Liberals leadership

image.altText: An illustration shows one woman with her hand to her forehead, on the phone, and another with her head in her hands

props.synopsis: Decriminalisation was meant to give women access to safe, affordable abortions as a form of health care. Five years on, the ABC can reveal glaring examples of the system failing people in rural and regional areas at almost every step.

title.children: Abortion is legal in Australia, but these women are being refused treatment. Doctors fear it's an 'unspoken ban'

image.altText: CCTV footage shows 'targeted' vandalism and theft at Canberra Hindu temple

props.synopsis: This is not the first time the buildings have been targeted by thieves and some community members say they are "horrified".

title.children: Two Hindu temples burgled, vandalised in broad daylight in Canberra

props.synopsis: Last year the ACT became the first Australian jurisdiction to decriminalise small amounts of illicit drugs. One year on, what has happened in the territory?

title.children: Small amounts of drugs were decriminalised in the ACT, but it didn't turn Canberra into our 'party capital'

image.altText: an elderly man in a colourful shirt

props.synopsis: Amid wider concerns about aged care sector fees, there are calls for more transparency to be introduced to retirement villages across the ACT.

title.children: 'A black hole': Calls for Canberra's retirement villages to be more transparent

image.altText: People queue while wearing masks

props.synopsis: Australia's COVID-19 response frayed after early successes, damaging the public's trust and making it unlikely that lockdowns or other harsh restrictions will be tolerated again, a federal government review has found.

title.children: Federal government to establish Centre for Disease Control in Canberra after COVID response review

image.altText: An older man in a red shirt standing in front of a tree

props.synopsis: When spraying crops, John O'Brien would end up covered in chemicals including paraquat. He's one of six farmers from Crookwell who say they have been diagnosed with Parkinson's Disease.

title.children: Six farmers who grew up in the same town near Goulburn getting 'covered' in chemicals now all have Parkinson's

image.altText: A sign outside a tertiary education campus

props.synopsis: Lawyers for consultancy company Think Garden owner Patrick Hollingworth tell the ACT Supreme Court the Canberra Institute of Technology's cancellation of their almost $5 million contact breached that same contract.

title.children: Consultancy company suing Canberra Institute of Technology for $3 million over cancelled contract

image.altText: A man standing in a workshop holds a wooden box closed.

props.synopsis: After years of collecting beautiful pieces of timber, Australian woodworker Scott Mitchell couldn't believe it when he was asked to craft part of a gift for King Charles III.

title.children: Meet the Australian woodworker who crafted a box fit for a king

image.altText: A man and woman, dressed in Trump clothing, look at a clipboard in a leafy suburban setting.

props.synopsis: With a week until election day, and a 0.2 per cent margin in the polls, the grassroots ground game in America's most high-stakes state is seeing some shifts in strategy.

title.children: 'I am terrified': The eleventh-hour tactics to win America's most critical battleground

image.altText: Bald man stands at podium wearing white shirt, pink tie and blue suit jacket

props.synopsis: Solomon Lew has fulfilled a long-held dream by taking the reins at Myer. But it has comes at a time when many shoppers and investors have grown tired of its business model and believe it belongs to a bygone era.

title.children: Solomon Lew rarely makes a bad deal but resurrecting Myer will be no easy task

image.altText: Trump gestures with one hand as he speaks at a podium in Mar-a-Lago

props.synopsis: Donald Trump says it was an "honour to be involved" in his New York rally, which he describes as "an absolute love fest". Follow live.

title.children: Donald Trump says New York rally marked by racist insults 'was like a love fest'

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Puerto Rico's largest newspaper endorses Harris for president
Trump describes Madison Square Garden rally as a 'love fest'

image.altText: kids in refugee camp

props.synopsis: The UN’s aid agency for Palestinian refugees will be outlawed in 90 days, under a controversial bill backed by Israel’s parliament.

title.children: Israel wants the UN aid agency for Palestinian refugees shut down within 90 days, but there may not be an alternative

image.altText: Houses along coast with water

props.synopsis: According to a handful of new research, the number of low-pressure systems around Australia is decreasing, bringing predictions of a future, dryer climate.

title.children: Australia's rainfall shifting as low-pressure systems become less frequent

image.altText: Children playing at a childcare centre

props.synopsis: About 12,000 early childhood educators are set to lock in a 10 per cent pay rise before Christmas.

title.children: Pay rises secured for 12,000 childcare workers in 'game changer' deal

image.altText: A black sign with green letters reading "For Lease, Apartment 1".

props.synopsis: "No fault" evictions will be banned, application fees scrapped and the cost of breaking a lease capped to four weeks' rent under new reforms proposed by the Victorian government.

title.children: Renters' rights in the spotlight as Victorian government announces six new reforms

image.altText: Google G logo outside a Google Store in New York City

props.synopsis: Google has been doing deals with Apple and Australian telcos Telstra and Optus to maintain it's supremacy. Now legal cases are posing an "existential threat". So how likely is a break up of the search giant?

title.children: The 'once in a generation' case that could see Google split up and tech changed forever

image.altText: A close up the face of an older Aboriginal man wearing a hat, with trees in the background.

props.synopsis: About 8,500 Aboriginal people who were underpaid or had their wages withheld due to discriminatory policy between 1936 and 1972 will be reimbursed by the state government following the court's decision.

title.children: Federal Court approves historic $180 million settlement over stolen Aboriginal wages in WA

image.altText: A woman holds up a shopping docket. She is sitting near some shopping bags.

props.synopsis: An Aboriginal elder who forks out more than 80 per cent of her income on groceries hopes the government can further subsidise the cost of transporting goods to her Gulf island community.

title.children: Remote island residents say they can hold $300 worth of groceries in one hand

image.altText: Black Hawks close up UH-60M

props.synopsis: The army staged a mock hostage rescue operation on Tuesday using three of the recently delivered UH-60M aircraft.

title.children: Army showcases new Black Hawk helicopters and confirms destruction of former Taipan fleet by year's end

image.altText: Two men talking to each other.

props.synopsis: Federal Nationals leader David Littleproud says he expects Queensland to fall into line on nuclear power if the Coalition wins the next federal election. What does the law say?

title.children: Going the nuclear option in Queensland would be 'hugely messy' for a future Dutton government, say legal experts

image.altText: a school sign showing emmanuel college

props.synopsis: A Gold Coast high school says it is appalled by content made by male students about their female peers and has taken action against them.

title.children: Police investigate after year 10 boys expelled over online content about female peers

image.altText: A woman takes a photo from a boat of an erupting volcano

props.synopsis: Whakaari Management argues that tour operators were responsible for the safety of visitors when the White Island volcano erupted in 2019, killing 22 people.

title.children: New Zealand White Island volcano owners launch appeal over conviction for deadly eruption

image.altText: A man with his fist raised.

props.synopsis: Argentina's president is hell-bent on fixing the country's economic woes, chainsaw in hand. But are his radical tactics working?

title.children: He's been called a cross between Donald Trump and Wolverine. Meet Argentina's new president, Javier 'El Loco' Milei

image.altText: An old photo of Keith Hyman held by Gary Lasky.

props.synopsis: The family of a man killed "execution-style" nearly 50 years ago at a jeweller's office in Melbourne's CBD has made a fresh appeal for information about his murder.

title.children: Family of man killed 'execution-style' in unsolved Melbourne murder call for police reward

image.altText: Chinese tennis player Zheng Qinwen waves to crowd in orange kit with blurred lights in background.

props.synopsis: Tennis has a rocky recent history in China — from #WhereIsPengShuai to Olympic gold. And some recent racism accusations have tarnished the sport as it grows more popular in the country.

title.children: Tennis is booming in China but not without courting controversy

image.altText: Donald Trump wearing a navy suit and wear tie at a campaign rally.

props.synopsis: Since 1912 the voters of Northampton County have only failed to correctly call the US election three times. They missed on Richard Nixon and George W Bush, twice. As Harris and Trump go head-to-head they are divided.

title.children: 'Orange Jesus': Northampton county nearly always votes for the winner in US elections. Trump has it divided

image.altText: Laminated sign in a window reading 'closed until further notice'

props.synopsis: Patients are disappointed after arriving at a Queensland clinic to find it closed, forcing them to find other healthcare options.

title.children: Patients left in limbo after urgent care clinic closes without explanation

image.altText: A woman pours a beer into a glass.

props.synopsis: A sensational season on the land is flowing into regional communities in northern NSW where populations swell as workers arrive to harvest crops.

title.children: Thirty-five kegs of beer and 20kg of bacon a week fuels tiny town's bumper harvest

image.altText: A man's torso can be seen with a white top on and a watch on his wrist. He's holding a pen in his write hand preparing to write.

props.synopsis: While serving time, these prisoners are helping authorities rewrite the way Victoria does criminal justice. Experts say it's best practice, but it's hard to get a clear answer from prison authorities.

title.children: Wireless phones are being used in Victorian prison cells, but why is it being kept so quiet?

image.altText: Sticker on a car window

props.synopsis: When Mitch McPherson ordered the first run of SPEAK UP! Stay ChatTY car stickers, he thought they'd end up in his wardrobe gathering dust. Eleven years later, the equivalent of one-in-six Tasmanians are sporting one.

title.children: These stickers are a common feature on cars across Tasmania, but there's a hidden meaning

image.altText: An empty movie theatre.

props.synopsis: The City of Sydney provides a "significant" rent reduction to Palace Cinemas to help ensure the Chauvel at Paddington Town Hall stays open.

title.children: Much-loved cinema's rent slashed by Sydney council after national chain threatens closure

image.altText: Jamshid Sharmahd wearing a blue face mask and jumpsuit while seated in a courtroom in front of a crowd of blurred supporters

props.synopsis: Iranian-born German citizen Jamshid Sharmahd had been held as a prisoner since 2020, accused of plotting attacks against Iran.

title.children: Germany threatens Iran with 'serious consequences' over dual national prisoner's execution

image.altText: Dylan Clancy poses with a ukelele during her time in a prison music program

props.synopsis: A music program run by singer-songwriter Nancy Bates has helped female inmates survive the daily challenges of prison. Now, a documentary is putting the initiative under the spotlight.

title.children: 'Without music, I'd probably be dead': How a unique program is helping women to survive prison
